6784292_syn_2:
OPERATIVE SUMMARY: Bronchoscopic management of GPA-associated airway stenosis.
PATIENT: 48-year-old male with Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis.
FINDINGS: Significant subglottic stenosis (approx. 79%) extending 1.5 cm. The stenosis was weblike in character.
INTERVENTION: Controlled radial expansion balloon dilation was performed sequentially to 14mm. Two inflation cycles were completed. 
OUTCOME: Residual stenosis reduced to approximately 17%. A minor mucosal tear was noted but required no intervention.

6784292_syn_8: [REDACTED] worsening stridor due to his GPA. We proceeded with bronchoscopic dilation. Upon entering the airway, we found a tight subglottic stenosis. We used a CRE balloon to dilate the area, stepping up the size from 10mm to 14mm. The airway responded well, opening up to near normal size. There was a small tear in the mucosa, which is expected, but no bleeding. He will be observed overnight.
6784292_syn_9:
DIAGNOSIS: GPA-related airway narrowing.
PROCEDURE: Scope with balloon expansion.
DETAILS: We found a weblike constriction in the subglottic area. We used a radial balloon to widen the passage. We expanded it to 14mm. The airway caliber improved greatly. A small tissue tear occurred. We admitted him for monitoring.
